meta.description: city agencies, departments, and intra-agency subviews

nodes.label: New York Police Department
nodes.factoid: Primary law enforcement agency for NYC with patrol, investigation, and counterterrorism responsibilities.

nodes.label: Fire Department of New York
nodes.factoid: Provides fire suppression, emergency medical services, and disaster response across all five boroughs.

nodes.label: Department of Education
nodes.factoid: Operates the nation's largest public school system serving over 1 million students in 1,800 schools.

nodes.label: Department of Health and Mental Hygiene
nodes.factoid: Protects and promotes public health through disease surveillance, health inspections, and mental health programs.

nodes.label: Department of Homeless Services
nodes.factoid: Provides shelter and services to homeless individuals and families and works to prevent homelessness.

nodes.label: Human Resources Administration
nodes.factoid: Administers public assistance programs including cash assistance, food stamps, and Medicaid enrollment.

nodes.label: Administration for Children's Services
nodes.factoid: Protects child welfare through foster care, child protective investigations, and preventive services.

nodes.label: Department of Housing Preservation and Development
nodes.factoid: Promotes affordable housing development, enforces housing code, and provides tenant protection services.

nodes.label: Department of Transportation
nodes.factoid: Maintains streets, bridges, sidewalks, and traffic signals while managing transportation infrastructure and policy.

nodes.label: Department of Sanitation
nodes.factoid: Collects residential waste and recyclables, cleans streets, and removes snow from 6,000 miles of city streets.

nodes.label: Department of Environmental Protection
nodes.factoid: Manages NYC's water supply system, wastewater treatment, and environmental quality enforcement.

nodes.label: Department of Parks and Recreation
nodes.factoid: Maintains over 30,000 acres of parkland, beaches, playgrounds, and recreational facilities citywide.

nodes.label: Department of City Planning
nodes.factoid: Shapes land use policy through zoning, environmental review, and comprehensive urban planning.

nodes.label: Department of Design and Construction
nodes.factoid: Designs and builds infrastructure projects including schools, firehouses, courthouses, and public facilities.

nodes.label: Landmarks Preservation Commission
nodes.factoid: Designates and regulates historic landmarks and districts to preserve NYC's architectural heritage.

nodes.label: Board of Standards and Appeals
nodes.factoid: Hears appeals from zoning and building code decisions and grants special permits and variances.

nodes.label: Office of Management and Budget
nodes.factoid: Prepares the city's annual budget, monitors agency spending, and manages fiscal planning.

nodes.label: Department of Finance
nodes.factoid: Collects property taxes, business taxes, and parking fines while maintaining property records.

nodes.label: Department of Citywide Administrative Services
nodes.factoid: Manages city facilities, procurement, fleet operations, and civil service hiring and personnel.

nodes.label: Mayor's Office of Contract Services
nodes.factoid: Oversees city procurement policy, contract registration, and vendor compliance programs.

nodes.label: Law Department
nodes.factoid: Serves as city's legal counsel, defending lawsuits and providing legal advice to city agencies.

nodes.label: Department of Investigation
nodes.factoid: Investigates corruption, fraud, and misconduct in city government and among city contractors.

nodes.label: Civilian Complaint Review Board
nodes.factoid: Independent agency investigating complaints of police misconduct including excessive force and abuse of authority.

nodes.label: Conflicts of Interest Board
nodes.factoid: Enforces conflicts of interest and financial disclosure requirements for city employees and officials.

nodes.label: Campaign Finance Board
nodes.factoid: Administers public financing for city elections and enforces campaign finance regulations.

nodes.label: Department of Buildings
nodes.factoid: Issues building permits, enforces construction codes, and ensures structural safety of buildings.

nodes.label: Department of Consumer and Worker Protection
nodes.factoid: Protects consumers and workers through licensing, enforcement, and education on workplace and marketplace rights.

nodes.label: Taxi and Limousine Commission
nodes.factoid: Licenses and regulates taxis, for-hire vehicles, and drivers including ride-sharing services.

nodes.label: Office of Administrative Trials and Hearings
nodes.factoid: Conducts administrative hearings and adjudicates summonses and violations issued by city agencies.

nodes.label: Business Integrity Commission
nodes.factoid: Regulates commercial waste hauling, public wholesale markets, and shipboard gambling to prevent organized crime.

nodes.label: Department of Youth and Community Development
nodes.factoid: Funds youth programs, literacy services, and community development initiatives through nonprofit partnerships.

nodes.label: Department for the Aging
nodes.factoid: Provides services for older New Yorkers including senior centers, meals, case management, and caregiver support.

nodes.label: Department of Veterans' Services
nodes.factoid: Connects military veterans to benefits, services, and resources including healthcare and housing assistance.

nodes.label: Department of Correction
nodes.factoid: Operates city jails including Rikers Island and provides custody and care for pretrial detainees.

nodes.label: Department of Cultural Affairs
nodes.factoid: Supports cultural institutions and arts organizations through grants and manages cultural facilities.

nodes.label: NYC Emergency Management
nodes.factoid: Coordinates citywide emergency preparedness, response, and recovery for natural and man-made disasters.

nodes.label: Department of Probation
nodes.factoid: Supervises individuals on probation and provides alternatives to incarceration for court-involved youth and adults.

nodes.label: Department of Records and Information Services
nodes.factoid: Manages city archives, records retention, and public access to historical government documents.

nodes.label: Department of Small Business Services
nodes.factoid: Supports small businesses and workforce development through training, financing, and neighborhood revitalization programs.

nodes.label: Office of Technology and Innovation
nodes.factoid: Manages citywide technology infrastructure, digital services, cybersecurity, and IT strategy for city agencies.

nodes.label: Office of Chief Medical Examiner
nodes.factoid: Investigates deaths, performs autopsies, maintains forensic laboratories, and identifies human remains.

nodes.label: NYC Sheriff's Office
nodes.factoid: Enforces civil judgments, seizes property, and conducts investigations related to consumer fraud and tax violations.

nodes.label: Equal Employment Practices Commission
nodes.factoid: Ensures equal employment opportunity in city government and reviews discrimination complaints from city employees.

nodes.label: Charter Revision Commission
nodes.factoid: Temporary commission appointed to review and propose amendments to the NYC Charter for voter approval.

nodes.label: City Council Member
nodes.factoid: Individual elected representative serving one of 51 council districts in the NYC City Council.

nodes.label: Mayor's Office of Operations
nodes.factoid: Reviews agency performance through the Mayor's Management Report and evaluates proposed agency rules.

nodes.label: NYC Voters
nodes.factoid: Registered voters who elect city officials and vote on ballot measures including charter amendments.

nodes.label: NYC Public
nodes.factoid: General public participating in city government through public hearings, comment periods, and civic engagement.

nodes.label: City Vendors
nodes.factoid: Private companies and organizations contracting with NYC to provide goods and services to city agencies.

nodes.label: Community Boards
nodes.factoid: 59 advisory bodies representing neighborhoods across NYC that review land use and service delivery issues.

nodes.label: Borough Presidents
nodes.factoid: Five elected borough-level executives with advisory roles in budget, land use, and appointment processes.

nodes.label: Patrol Bureau
nodes.factoid: Largest NYPD bureau responsible for uniformed patrol, neighborhood policing, 911 response, and precinct operations across all five boroughs with approximately 22,000 officers.

nodes.label: Detective Bureau
nodes.factoid: Investigates major crimes including homicides, robberies, gang activity, and cold cases through specialized detective squads and borough investigative units citywide.

nodes.label: Transit Bureau
nodes.factoid: Dedicated to policing the NYC subway system and buses, conducting patrol, enforcement, and investigations within the MTA transit network.

nodes.label: Housing Bureau
nodes.factoid: Provides police services to NYCHA public housing developments with dedicated officers serving residents in housing projects across the city.

nodes.label: Counterterrorism Bureau
nodes.factoid: Protects NYC from terrorist threats through intelligence gathering, critical infrastructure protection, strategic planning, and coordination with federal agencies.

nodes.label: Intelligence Bureau
nodes.factoid: Collects and analyzes intelligence on criminal and terrorist threats, manages informants, and coordinates with federal and international law enforcement agencies.

nodes.label: Internal Affairs Bureau
nodes.factoid: Investigates allegations of corruption and misconduct by NYPD officers, ensuring integrity and accountability within the department through independent investigations.

nodes.label: Division of Instructional and Informational Technology
nodes.factoid: Manages educational technology infrastructure, digital learning platforms, student information systems, and technology integration across 1,800 schools serving over one million students.

nodes.label: Division of School Quality
nodes.factoid: Oversees school performance through superintendent networks, conducts school quality reviews, and provides support to improve academic outcomes and school leadership.

nodes.label: Division of Early Childhood Education
nodes.factoid: Administers Pre-K for All, 3-K programs, and early childhood services across community-based organizations and public schools, serving approximately 100,000 young children.

nodes.label: Division of Multilingual Learners
nodes.factoid: Supports English Language Learners and multilingual students through curriculum development, teacher training, and bilingual education programs in over 180 languages.

nodes.label: Division of Special Education
nodes.factoid: Provides special education services and IEP implementation for over 200,000 students with disabilities through specialized programs, related services, and accommodations.

nodes.label: Division of School Facilities
nodes.factoid: Manages capital planning, construction, maintenance, and facility operations for over 1,800 school buildings, ensuring safe and functional learning environments.

nodes.label: Bureau of Audit
nodes.factoid: Conducts financial and performance audits of city agencies, programs, and contracts to ensure proper use of public funds and identify waste or fraud.

nodes.label: Bureau of Asset Management
nodes.factoid: Manages over $250 billion in pension fund investments for five NYC retirement systems, making allocation decisions across equities, bonds, real estate, and alternative investments.

nodes.label: Bureau of Accountancy
nodes.factoid: Processes payroll for all city employees, maintains accounting records, produces financial reports, and ensures compliance with governmental accounting standards.

nodes.label: Bureau of Public Finance
nodes.factoid: Issues and manages city bonds and other debt instruments, monitors city revenues and budget execution, and provides fiscal analysis and forecasting.

nodes.label: Budget Division
nodes.factoid: Prepares the Mayor's executive budget, analyzes agency budget requests, monitors spending throughout fiscal year, and develops financial plans for the city.

nodes.label: Economic and Revenue Analysis
nodes.factoid: Forecasts city tax revenues, analyzes economic trends affecting NYC, produces economic reports, and provides revenue projections for budget planning.

nodes.label: Operations Unit
nodes.factoid: Monitors agency performance metrics, conducts operational reviews, manages mayoral management reports, and tracks service delivery indicators across city government.

nodes.label: Management Analysis
nodes.factoid: Conducts organizational studies, evaluates program effectiveness, recommends management improvements, and analyzes city operations for efficiency and cost savings.

nodes.label: Bureau of Fire Operations
nodes.factoid: Commands all fire suppression operations through 218 firehouses, responds to structure fires, hazardous materials incidents, and technical rescue calls citywide.

nodes.label: Bureau of Emergency Medical Services
nodes.factoid: Operates citywide emergency medical services with 400+ ambulances responding to over 1.5 million medical emergencies annually through 46 EMS stations.

nodes.label: Bureau of Fire Prevention
nodes.factoid: Conducts building inspections, enforces fire safety codes, issues permits for fire alarm systems, and investigates fires to determine cause and origin.

nodes.label: Bureau of Training
nodes.factoid: Trains all FDNY firefighters and EMTs through Fire Academy and EMS Academy, provides continuing education, and maintains training facilities on Randall's Island.

nodes.label: Bureau of Cleaning and Collection
nodes.factoid: Collects over 12,000 tons of residential and institutional waste daily, maintains street cleanliness through mechanical broom operations, and empties 25,000 public litter baskets.

nodes.label: Bureau of Recycling and Sustainability
nodes.factoid: Manages citywide recycling programs including curbside collection of paper, metal, glass, and plastic, operates special waste drop-off sites, and promotes waste reduction.

nodes.label: Bureau of Motor Equipment
nodes.factoid: Maintains and repairs DSNY's fleet of over 6,000 collection trucks, sweepers, and specialized vehicles through 12 repair shops across the city.

nodes.label: Adult Family Services
nodes.factoid: Provides shelter, supportive housing, and services to adult families experiencing homelessness through a network of shelters and transitional housing facilities.

nodes.label: Family Services
nodes.factoid: Operates family shelters, provides case management, and coordinates services for families with children experiencing homelessness to support transition to permanent housing.

nodes.label: Prevention Services
nodes.factoid: Administers rental assistance programs, eviction prevention services, and emergency grants to help at-risk households avoid entering the shelter system.

nodes.label: Outreach and Intake
nodes.factoid: Conducts street outreach through HOME-STAT teams, operates intake centers for shelter placement, and connects unsheltered individuals to services and housing.

nodes.label: Office of Adult Services
nodes.factoid: Provides support services to vulnerable adults including home care, protective services, and assistance programs for elderly and disabled New Yorkers.

nodes.label: Family Independence Administration
nodes.factoid: Administers cash assistance programs including Family Assistance and Safety Net, SNAP benefits, and employment services to support low-income families toward self-sufficiency.

nodes.label: HIV/AIDS Services Administration
nodes.factoid: Provides supportive housing, case management, and emergency assistance to New Yorkers living with HIV/AIDS through a network of specialized services.

nodes.label: Medical Assistance Program
nodes.factoid: Processes Medicaid applications, determines eligibility for health coverage programs, and coordinates with NYC Health + Hospitals for healthcare access.

nodes.label: Division of Traffic Operations
nodes.factoid: Manages 12,700 traffic signals, implements traffic calming measures, coordinates street closures and special events, and monitors traffic flow through traffic management center.

nodes.label: Division of Infrastructure
nodes.factoid: Designs and constructs street reconstruction projects, sidewalk repairs, bike lanes, and pedestrian safety improvements across 6,300 miles of city streets.

nodes.label: Division of Bridges
nodes.factoid: Maintains and rehabilitates 789 bridges including East River bridges, inspects bridge structures for safety, and manages major capital reconstruction projects.

nodes.label: Division of Ferries
nodes.factoid: Operates NYC Ferry service with six routes connecting waterfront communities, manages ferry infrastructure including landing facilities, and coordinates marine transportation.

nodes.label: Division of Housing Preservation
nodes.factoid: Administers rental assistance programs, manages affordable housing lotteries, and provides resources to tenants and landlords to preserve existing affordable housing stock.

nodes.label: Division of Housing Development
nodes.factoid: Finances new affordable housing construction, manages tax incentive programs like 421-a, and partners with developers to create income-restricted housing units.

nodes.label: Division of Code Enforcement
nodes.factoid: Inspects residential buildings for housing code violations, issues violations for unsafe conditions, and can initiate emergency repairs or legal action against negligent landlords.

nodes.label: Division of Neighborhood Preservation
nodes.factoid: Supports community-based organizations providing housing counseling, homeownership programs, and neighborhood revitalization initiatives to strengthen communities.

nodes.label: Bureau of Communicable Disease
nodes.factoid: Monitors and responds to infectious disease outbreaks, conducts disease surveillance, manages TB control programs, and coordinates immunization efforts across the city.

nodes.label: Bureau of Vital Statistics
nodes.factoid: Maintains official records of births, deaths, and marriages in NYC, issues birth and death certificates, and produces vital statistics reports for public health planning.

nodes.label: Bureau of Mental Health
nodes.factoid: Provides mental health services through clinics, coordinates crisis intervention, operates ThriveNYC programs, and supports community mental health providers citywide.

nodes.label: Bureau of Environmental Health
nodes.factoid: Enforces health code regulations for restaurants and food establishments, conducts inspections, manages letter grading system, and investigates foodborne illness complaints.

nodes.label: Chief of Staff to the Mayor
nodes.factoid: Oversees the Mayor's senior staff and coordinates policy initiatives across city agencies.

nodes.label: First Deputy Mayor
nodes.factoid: Serves as the Mayor's principal advisor and manages day-to-day operations of City Hall.

nodes.label: Deputy Mayor for Strategic Policy Initiatives
nodes.factoid: Leads long-term policy planning and coordinates cross-agency strategic initiatives.

nodes.label: Deputy Mayor for Health and Human Services
nodes.factoid: Oversees health, mental health, social services, and homelessness agencies and programs.

nodes.label: Deputy Mayor for Housing and Economic Development
nodes.factoid: Leads housing policy, affordable housing development, and economic growth initiatives.

nodes.label: Deputy Mayor for Public Safety
nodes.factoid: Coordinates NYPD, FDNY, Corrections, and emergency management to ensure public safety.

nodes.label: Deputy Mayor for Operations
nodes.factoid: Manages operational agencies including sanitation, transportation, buildings, and parks.

nodes.label: Counsel to the Mayor
nodes.factoid: Provides legal advice to the Mayor and reviews all legislation, contracts, and executive orders.

nodes.label: Director of Mayor's Office of Operations
nodes.factoid: Tracks agency performance metrics and publishes the Mayor's Management Report.

nodes.label: Press Secretary
nodes.factoid: Manages media relations, press briefings, and the Mayor's public communications.

nodes.label: Director of Intergovernmental Affairs
nodes.factoid: Coordinates relationships with federal, state, and local government officials.

nodes.label: Speaker of the Council
nodes.factoid: Leads the City Council, sets legislative agenda, and assigns committee chairs.

nodes.label: Majority Leader
nodes.factoid: Assists the Speaker in managing the legislative agenda and building consensus among members.

nodes.label: Finance Committee
nodes.factoid: Reviews the city budget, monitors revenue and expenditures, and oversees fiscal policy.

nodes.label: Land Use Committee
nodes.factoid: Reviews all land use applications including rezonings, special permits, and ULURP projects.

nodes.label: Public Safety Committee
nodes.factoid: Oversees NYPD, FDNY, emergency management, and corrections policies and operations.

nodes.label: Transportation Committee
nodes.factoid: Oversees DOT, street safety, transit policy, and transportation infrastructure.

nodes.label: Education Committee
nodes.factoid: Oversees DOE, school policies, education funding, and student services.

nodes.label: Health Committee
nodes.factoid: Oversees DOHMH, public health programs, healthcare access, and health facilities.

nodes.label: General Welfare Committee
nodes.factoid: Oversees DHS, HRA, social services, homelessness programs, and public assistance.

nodes.label: Operating Budget
nodes.factoid: FY2024 operating budget: ~$107 billion

nodes.label: Capital Budget
nodes.factoid: FY2024-2028 capital commitment plan: ~$160 billion over 4 years

nodes.label: Property Tax Revenue
nodes.factoid: Generates ~$32 billion annually (45% of tax revenue)

nodes.label: Personal Income Tax
nodes.factoid: Generates ~$15 billion annually (21% of tax revenue)

nodes.label: Sales Tax Revenue
nodes.factoid: Generates ~$9 billion annually (13% of tax revenue)

nodes.label: State & Federal Aid
nodes.factoid: ~$20 billion annually from state and federal sources

nodes.label: Debt Service
nodes.factoid: ~$7 billion annually (7% of operating budget)

nodes.label: Pension Contributions
nodes.factoid: ~$10 billion annually (9% of operating budget)

nodes.label: Agency Operating Allocations
nodes.factoid: ~$90 billion allocated to 70+ city agencies

nodes.label: Capital Project Allocations
nodes.factoid: ~$160B committed over 4-year plan

nodes.label: Bureau of Audit
nodes.factoid: Performs ~30 audits annually of agencies, contracts, and programs

nodes.label: Bureau of Asset Management
nodes.factoid: Invests $250B+ across Teachers, Police, Fire, Employees, Board of Ed pension systems

nodes.label: Bureau of Accountancy
nodes.factoid: Processes payroll for 300,000+ city employees twice monthly

nodes.label: Bureau of Public Finance
nodes.factoid: Issues $8-10 billion in bonds annually to fund capital projects

nodes.label: NYC Pension Funds
nodes.factoid: Five systems: NYCERS (general employees), TRS (teachers), POLICE, FIRE, BERS (Board of Ed)

subviews.label: NYPD Internal Structure
subviews.description: Major operational bureaus within the New York Police Department organized by function and jurisdiction

subviews.label: DOE Internal Structure
subviews.description: Major operational divisions within the NYC Department of Education managing instructional, student, and facility services

subviews.label: OMB Internal Structure
subviews.description: Major divisions within the Office of Management and Budget responsible for budget preparation, economic analysis, and agency oversight

subviews.label: FDNY Internal Structure
subviews.description: Major operational bureaus within the Fire Department managing fire suppression, EMS, prevention, and training services

subviews.label: DSNY Internal Structure
subviews.description: Major operational bureaus within the Department of Sanitation managing waste collection, recycling, and fleet maintenance

subviews.label: DHS Internal Structure
subviews.description: Major service divisions within the Department of Homeless Services managing shelter operations, prevention programs, and outreach

subviews.label: HRA Internal Structure
subviews.description: Major service administrations within the Human Resources Administration providing public assistance, HIV/AIDS services, and healthcare access

subviews.label: DOT Internal Structure
subviews.description: Major operational divisions within the Department of Transportation managing traffic operations, infrastructure, bridges, and ferry services

subviews.label: HPD Internal Structure
subviews.description: Major operational divisions within Housing Preservation and Development managing affordable housing preservation, development, code enforcement, and neighborhood programs

subviews.label: DOHMH Internal Structure
subviews.description: Major operational bureaus within the Department of Health and Mental Hygiene managing disease control, vital records, mental health, and environmental health

subviews.label: Budget Structure
subviews.description: NYC Budget divided into Operating Budget (annual expenses) and Capital Budget (infrastructure/long-term projects)

edges.detail: Budget includes Operating Budget for annual expenses
Budget includes Capital Budget for infrastructure projects

subviews.label: Revenue Sources
subviews.description: Where NYC's money comes from - tax revenues and intergovernmental aid

edges.detail: Property tax revenue flows into city budget (45% of tax revenue)
Personal income tax flows into city budget (21% of tax revenue)
Sales tax revenue flows into city budget (13% of tax revenue)
State and federal grants flow into city budget for specific programs

subviews.label: Budget Allocations
subviews.description: Where NYC's money goes - major spending categories

edges.detail: Operating budget allocates $90B+ to city agencies for personnel and programs
Capital budget allocates $160B over 4 years for infrastructure projects
Budget allocates $7B annually for debt service (bond payments)
Budget allocates $10B annually for pension contributions (constitutionally required)

subviews.label: Complete Money Flow
subviews.description: End-to-end view: revenue collection → budget → spending

edges.detail: Budget includes Operating Budget for annual expenses
Budget includes Capital Budget for infrastructure projects
Property tax revenue flows into city budget (45% of tax revenue)
Personal income tax flows into city budget (21% of tax revenue)
Sales tax revenue flows into city budget (13% of tax revenue)
State and federal grants flow into city budget for specific programs
Operating budget allocates $90B+ to city agencies for personnel and programs
Capital budget allocates $160B over 4 years for infrastructure projects
Budget allocates $7B annually for debt service (bond payments)
Budget allocates $10B annually for pension contributions (constitutionally required)

subviews.label: Comptroller Bureaus
subviews.description: Internal organization of the NYC Comptroller's Office - four major bureaus handling audits, pensions, accounting, and public finance

edges.detail: Comptroller's office includes Bureau of Audit
Comptroller's office includes Bureau of Asset Management
Comptroller's office includes Bureau of Accountancy
Comptroller's office includes Bureau of Public Finance

subviews.label: Financial Oversight Process
subviews.description: How the Comptroller provides checks on city spending and operations

edges.detail: Comptroller's office includes Bureau of Audit
Comptroller's office includes Bureau of Accountancy
Audit Bureau conducts financial and performance audits of city agencies
Accountancy Bureau registers budget after Council adoption, making it official
Accountancy Bureau must register contracts before agencies can spend

subviews.label: Pension Fund Management
subviews.description: Comptroller's control over massive pension fund investments

edges.detail: Comptroller's office includes Bureau of Asset Management
Asset Management Bureau invests and manages $250B in pension assets

subviews.label: NYC Pension Investment Allocation
subviews.description: Detailed breakdown of $301.7B NYC pension fund investments from 5 systems through asset classes to individual investment managers

subviews.label: NYC FY2025 Expense Budget by Revenue Source
subviews.description: Flow of NYC FY2025 expense budget from revenue classes through specific sources and funds to government functions

subviews.label: NYC Expense Budget FY2026
subviews.description: Interactive hierarchical breakdown of $115.8B NYC City Funds expense budget by agency, program, and expenditure category

subviews.label: NYC Revenue Breakdown FY2025
subviews.description: Interactive hierarchical breakdown of $120.5B NYC revenue sources from funding types through revenue categories to individual sources
